2013-07-27 07:36:03	christi123	moment

2013-07-27 07:37:21	rtnpro	thanks to sayan
2013-07-27 07:37:30	sayan	christi123, remove the time.py file from /home/user/, along with the *.pyc file
2013-07-27 07:37:44	rtnpro	christi123: flask tries importing all the files in the current dir

2013-07-23 17:04:32	Armageddon	b

2013-07-17 11:05:19	ncoghlan	kushal asked me to start by explaining how I got started with Python, so that's what I'll do :)
2013-07-17 11:05:48	ncoghlan	these days I work almost entirely on Linux, but I didn't get started with Python that way
2013-07-17 11:05:51	J_Caselles	Josep Caselles
2013-07-17 11:06:10	ncoghlan	my first job out of university was programming digital signal processors
2013-07-17 11:06:24	ncoghlan	and we had a lot of problems with defects getting through my testing
2013-07-17 11:06:47	ncoghlan	so I needed a better way to run unit tests on a Windows NT host, to test the behaviour of the DSPs
2013-07-17 11:06:54	manishjain2792	manish
2013-07-17 11:07:11	ncoghlan	the project was way over budget already, so "free" was major factor in choosing something
2013-07-17 11:07:41	ncoghlan	the Python 2.2.2 unittest module + SWIG to wrap our custom DSP driver module was my answer
2013-07-17 11:08:20	ncoghlan	I found I rather liked the language, and started hanging out on python-list/comp.lang.python and python-dev
2013-07-17 11:08:49	ncoghlan	I'm too opinionated to lurk very well, so I started participating actively on both lists rather than just reading
2013-07-17 11:09:16	ncoghlan	eventually the python-list volume got too much for me to keep up with so, so I don't read that any more :(
2013-07-17 11:09:59	ncoghlan	around 2004 I think I submitted my first patch - one of those ones where a mailing list discussion had been spinning on for a while
2013-07-17 11:10:13	ncoghlan	and the best way to end it seemed to be to just provide some code
2013-07-17 11:10:30	ncoghlan	and thus Python 2.4 came with the -m switch to run a top level module as a script
2013-07-17 11:10:56	ncoghlan	and then it took me until Python 2.7 to actually finish making the thing work properly ;)
2013-07-17 11:11:40	ncoghlan	(from another point of view, it only *really* works properly in 3.3 - that's the first time it is using the true import system rather than an emulation)
2013-07-17 11:12:45	ncoghlan	my path to becoming a core developer probably isn't one I'd recommend as a general tactic: I got commit privileges by arguing with Guido about a PEP he wrote :)
2013-07-17 11:13:17	ncoghlan	that was PEP 340, his original "block" PEP that was... mind-blowing
2013-07-17 11:13:37	ncoghlan	incredibly powerful proposal, incredibly mind-bending to try to figure out when and how you would use it
2013-07-17 11:13:59	--	rahulch_ is now known as rahulch
2013-07-17 11:14:23	ncoghlan	I wasn't the only one who had issues with it, but I was the one who had the time and inclination to write a competing PEP (eventually published on python.org as PEP 436)
2013-07-17 11:14:35	ncoghlan	err, 346 rather
2013-07-17 11:15:10	ncoghlan	Guido didn't like my specific proposal, but he could see merit in some of the objections
2013-07-17 11:15:32	ncoghlan	so he rejected both his own PEP and mine, and we ended up with two other PEPs
2013-07-17 11:15:44	ncoghlan	PEP 342, which added the send() and throw() methods to generators
2013-07-17 11:16:18	ncoghlan	and one which has consequences most pythonistas will be familiar with: PEP 343, which added context managers and the with statement to the language
2013-07-17 11:17:22	ncoghlan	the way I ended up with commit privileges out of all that, is that Guido gave them to me when PEP 343 needed some significant updates, and he didn't have time to do them himself :)
2013-07-17 11:18:06	ncoghlan	it's a roundabout way to get commit privileges, though - most sensible people do it by being active on the issue tracker and providing multple good patches
2013-07-17 11:18:15	ncoghlan	without the "arguing with Guido" part :)
2013-07-17 11:19:01	ncoghlan	he's a very smart fellow and we're lucky to have him as Python's BDFL, but that isn't the same thing as always being right :)
2013-07-17 11:19:30	--	kirk is now known as Guest69994
2013-07-17 11:20:30	ncoghlan	and *being* a core developer isn't all that different from *becoming* a core developer - write patches, review patches, participated in design discussions
2013-07-17 11:20:54	ncoghlan	the additional power we get is to say "yes, that's a good idea, we'll do that" :)
2013-07-17 11:21:40	ncoghlan	shall we move on to the Q&A now?

2013-07-17 11:26:01	pjp	ncoghlan: for a new Python programmer, is bugzilla/mailing-list best places to look for opportunities to contribute? Or starting small projects is a way to go??
2013-07-17 11:26:09	ncoghlan	pingou: I joined the lists because I liked the language, I stayed because the people are awesome
2013-07-17 11:26:39	ncoghlan	pjp: I think the most important thing is for people to do something *they* find interesting...
2013-07-17 11:27:18	ncoghlan	when we set up things like pythonmentors.com/core-mentorship@python.org, we're trying to guess at what people might find interesting
2013-07-17 11:27:21	ncoghlan	...
2013-07-17 11:27:22	+batul	ncoghlan: Error: ".." is not a valid command.
2013-07-17 11:27:30	@kushal	:)
2013-07-17 11:27:54	@kushal	ncoghlan, that is our bot, takes command with anything starting with a .
2013-07-17 11:27:54	ncoghlan	but we sometimes get people diving in to quite complex things - one first patch we received was to fix a bug in the metaclass resolution order
2013-07-17 11:28:21	@kushal	piotrektt, ask
2013-07-17 11:29:12	piotrektt	well, my question was being answered all the time so I change it a little bit. You said that python interested you. Was there some feature or anything else in particular that makes python "cool"?
2013-07-17 11:29:22	pjp	ncoghlan: true, thank you!
2013-07-17 11:30:01	ncoghlan	piotrektt: I think the part that most interested me was simply Guido's approach to language design
2013-07-17 11:30:29	piotrektt	you mean that it is so human like? :P
2013-07-17 11:30:40	ncoghlan	piotrektt: well, Guido and the rest of the Python Labs team
2013-07-17 11:30:48	ncoghlan	more so the Zen of Python, and the ideas behind it
2013-07-17 11:31:00	ncoghlan	especially "Readability counts"
2013-07-17 11:31:21	ncoghlan	<continuing?
2013-07-17 11:31:45	ncoghlan	I'm one of those people that likes writing almost as much as coding
2013-07-17 11:31:54	ncoghlan	(hence my fondness for email)
2013-07-17 11:32:03	ncoghlan	so Python is a very appealing language to me
2013-07-17 11:32:21	ncoghlan	whereas languages that are too symbol heavy irritate me
2013-07-17 11:32:43	@kushal	ncoghlan, can you tell few points on why/how learning Python or doing projects during college days using Python is helpful for students ?
2013-07-17 11:32:48	sayan	!
2013-07-17 11:33:31	ncoghlan	kushal: one of the best things about Python is that I think it fits the "easy to learn, difficult to master" pattern you want in a truly powerful tool
2013-07-17 11:33:55	ncoghlan	we have some incredibly sophisticated capabilities in the language, like metaclasses and import hooks
2013-07-17 11:34:06	ncoghlan	but we tell people not to use them unless the *really* need them
2013-07-17 11:34:25	ncoghlan	"do the simplest thing that could possible work" is something Python tries hard to enable
2013-07-17 11:34:44	ncoghlan	by we try to make sure the power tools are still there for when you need them
2013-07-17 11:34:47	ncoghlan	*but we
2013-07-17 11:35:08	@kushal	sayan, ask
2013-07-17 11:35:39	piotrektt	!
2013-07-17 11:35:50	ravi_pro	!
2013-07-17 11:35:51	sayan	ncoghlan, you told about pythonmentors.com, are there mentored bugs in Python? how do we identify them?<eof>
2013-07-17 11:36:01	rtnpro_	sayan, +1
2013-07-17 11:36:21	ncoghlan	sayan: we try to mark bugs that we think are good starting points with "easy" in the tracker
2013-07-17 11:36:36	ncoghlan	but the standard library is so bug, it's hard to use that flag appropriately
2013-07-17 11:37:04	@kushal	piotrektt, ask
2013-07-17 11:38:20	piotrektt	I just wanted to point you guys to the Zen of Python, Nick mentioned http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0020/  it's a Python Enchancement Proposal. So cool! :)
2013-07-17 11:38:52	ncoghlan	also try "python -m this" in your shell :)

2013-07-17 11:39:15	ravi_pro	ncoghlan , mainly in every programming language logic design is very important, So how can we develop LOGIC for any real life program?
2013-07-17 11:39:21	ncoghlan	oh, and "python -m antigravity" :)
2013-07-17 11:39:36	piotrektt	*enhancement
2013-07-17 11:39:55	ravi_pro	<eof>
2013-07-17 11:39:59	ncoghlan	ravi_pro: ultimately, I think every program comes down to a modelling exercise
2013-07-17 11:40:32	ncoghlan	you have to figure out what output you want, what inputs you have available, and what you need to do to get from those inputs to the desired outputs
2013-07-17 11:41:04	ncoghlan	so the first two questions to ask are usually
2013-07-17 11:41:13	ncoghlan	1. What outcome do I need?
2013-07-17 11:41:21	ncoghlan	2. What inputs are available?
2013-07-17 11:41:25	pjp	!
2013-07-17 11:41:51	ncoghlan	from there, it gets much harder to generalise - I'm still figuring it out :)
2013-07-17 11:42:09	ncoghlan	oh, and you have to factor in "how long do I have" as well :P
2013-07-17 11:42:30	ncoghlan	<eom>
2013-07-17 11:42:43	@kushal	pjp, ask
2013-07-17 11:42:53	ravi_pro	ncoghlan, thanks
2013-07-17 11:43:26	pjp	ncoghlan: as python student - what were some of the exercises you did for practice?
2013-07-17 11:44:06	ncoghlan	pjp: I was already an experienced C/C++ developer when I learned Python, so I don't actually have an answer to that
2013-07-17 11:44:31	ravi_pro	!
2013-07-17 11:44:36	pjp	ncoghlan: ah I see, cool!
2013-07-17 11:44:52	@kushal	ravi_pro, ask
2013-07-17 11:45:08	ravi_pro	ncoghlan, which part in python language we will have to make strong?
2013-07-17 11:45:43	ravi_pro	ncoghlan, sothat we can be a developer in python
2013-07-17 11:46:11	ncoghlan	ah, OK - thanks for the clarification
2013-07-17 11:46:48	ncoghlan	hmm, in some regards it depends on exactly the kinds of problems you're trying to solve
2013-07-17 11:47:18	ncoghlan	the universal elements are being able to *use* things like functions, iterators and context managers effectively
2013-07-17 11:47:29	ncoghlan	and classes
2013-07-17 11:47:39	ncoghlan	since most APIs will be built around those four things
2013-07-17 11:47:59	ncoghlan	and a lot of the time, what we do as programmers is taking an existing API that solves a problem in general
2013-07-17 11:48:06	ncoghlan	and applying it to our particular case
2013-07-17 11:48:26	ncoghlan	the "next level" is then learning to create those things ourselves
2013-07-17 11:48:46	ncoghlan	since that provides for more powerful tools for avoid code repetition and that kind of thing
2013-07-17 11:49:14	ncoghlan	beyond that, it's really a matter of honing our *problem solving* skills
2013-07-17 11:49:25	ncoghlan	learning to ask the right questions, learning how to research good answers
2013-07-17 11:49:58	ncoghlan	one way to describe being a developer is "using computers to solve our own and other people's problems" :)
2013-07-17 11:50:21	ncoghlan	and Python just happens to be a very effective way of telling computers what to do :)
2013-07-17 11:51:08	ravi_pro	ncoghlan, the problem with me regarding *problem solving skill*
2013-07-17 11:51:30	ncoghlan	can I digress a moment to talk about some things that *I've* been excited to learn about recently?
2013-07-17 11:51:38	@kushal	ncoghlan, go ahead
2013-07-17 11:51:39	@kushal	:)
2013-07-17 11:51:56	ncoghlan	IPython Notebook is pretty spectacular
2013-07-17 11:52:35	ncoghlan	I've started using it for things I would have previously written ad hoc scripts for, and it's just a much better way of working
2013-07-17 11:52:57	ncoghlan	and you can share the results by saving the notebook as a HTML file
2013-07-17 11:53:12	--	shalini is now known as shalini_
2013-07-17 11:53:30	ncoghlan	there's a lot of good scientific software related to that, too
2013-07-17 11:53:44	 *	kushal notes that IPython Notebook will be in a separate session 
2013-07-17 11:53:52	ncoghlan	the other one which people may have heard of is the "requests" library
2013-07-17 11:54:05	ncoghlan	a lot of the networking APIs in the stdlib are quite old
2013-07-17 11:54:30	--	rahulch_ is now known as rahulch
2013-07-17 11:54:42	ncoghlan	before HTTP really won the network protocol wars for the request/response layer above TCP.
2013-07-17 11:55:13	ncoghlan	so you need to do a bunch of configuration to do any HTTP specific configuration (beyond a basic GET call)
2013-07-17 11:55:27	ncoghlan	requests is far more recent, so it does a lot more for you
2013-07-17 11:55:45	ncoghlan	and ends up being much easier to use, since so many good defaults are encoded into the library
2013-07-17 11:56:22	ncoghlan	I think those are the main two I wanted to share
2013-07-17 11:56:31	@kushal	pasting another question from navid_
2013-07-17 11:56:37	@kushal	<navid_> ncoghlan, please talk about test driven development in python, how/at which extent,  you use it in core development?
2013-07-17 11:57:11	ncoghlan	so, there's the purist definition of test driven development, which says it has to be test *first* development
2013-07-17 11:57:30	ncoghlan	I think that can be a good way to go, especially if you're trying to fix an existing bug
2013-07-17 11:57:39	ncoghlan	first write a test that fails, then make it pass
2013-07-17 11:58:18	ncoghlan	however, the only rule we enforce in the standard library is that, wherever practical, any change must be accompanied by a test for that change
2013-07-17 11:58:27	zishan	kya wahi
2013-07-17 11:58:33	ncoghlan	I used the same rule for beaker-project.org
2013-07-17 11:58:54	ncoghlan	the exceptions are cases where it's not practical to write a robust test
2013-07-17 11:59:11	ncoghlan	fragile tests that fail intermittently are often worse than not having the test at all
2013-07-17 11:59:13	--	Mode #dgplug [-v zishan] by kushal
2013-07-17 11:59:30	ncoghlan	since they cause false alarms in continuous integration systems
2013-07-17 12:00:01	ncoghlan	I've written software with and without good regression test suites
2013-07-17 12:00:19	ncoghlan	and without the test suite, you're taking huge risks any time you make even a small change
2013-07-17 12:00:49	ncoghlan	whereas with a solid test suite, you can make big changes, confident that the externally visible behaviour will remain the same
2013-07-17 12:01:24	ncoghlan	was anyone here at PyCon India last year?
2013-07-17 12:01:39	 *	kushal was
2013-07-17 12:01:44	 *	rtnpro_ was
2013-07-17 12:01:56	chandankumar	*/me was
2013-07-17 12:02:06	 *	chandankumar was
2013-07-17 12:02:39	@kushal	sayan, was also there
2013-07-17 12:02:46	sayan	ncoghlan, me
2013-07-17 12:02:48	ncoghlan	I gave a longer version of this Path Dependent Development talk (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PYw2K0_ZZ0w) there
2013-07-17 12:03:37	ncoghlan	and one of my points was that if the industry has pretty much figured out that if you're trying to improve a software product
2013-07-17 12:03:57	ncoghlan	then working out how to start building a test suite for it is a key milestone
2013-07-17 12:04:15	ncoghlan	because getting the test suite in place then gives you the freedom to start fixing everything else
2013-07-17 12:05:20	ncoghlan	we're able to make fairly deep changes to CPython (like replacing the whole import system) without most users even noticing when they upgrade
2013-07-17 12:05:56	ncoghlan	and it's the regression test suite, and the buildbot fleet that give us the power to do that

2013-07-19 15:17:00	piotrektt	from virtualenv documentation:
2013-07-19 15:17:02	piotrektt	This creates ENV/lib/pythonX.X/site-packages, where any libraries you install will go. It also creates ENV/bin/python, which is a Python interpreter that uses this environment. Anytime you use that interpreter (including when a script has #!/path/to/ENV/bin/python in it) the libraries in that environment will be used.
2013-07-19 15:20:25	J_Caselles	mmm, didn't know about this, but if you write this shebang, this script will only work on your virtualenv
2013-07-19 15:21:20	piotrektt	but when you don't and if you try to run a program that has libraries that are only in virtual env will it work?
2013-07-19 15:21:37	J_Caselles	yes

2013-07-19 15:22:37	J_Caselles	normally you would leave the same shebang, #!/usr/bin/env python, and if you have your virtualenv activated, you will be working on this virtualenv, with whichever modules are installed in

2013-07-25 14:42:46	@pingou	since only J_Caselles seems to know what frameworks are, I'll just explain it in a sentence
2013-07-25 14:43:08	@pingou	they are a group of libraries that you can use to create an application, the idea is that they make your life easier
2013-07-25 14:43:42	@pingou	flask, pyramid, turbogears, django are example of web framework
2013-07-25 14:43:55	manishjain2792	a certain type of package that will help to create application, am i right ? pingou.
2013-07-25 14:43:57	@pingou	flask is part of the family of the so-called, micro-framework
2013-07-25 14:44:22	@pingou	manishjain2792: not a type really, more a set of packages, but yes, the idea is that they help you
2013-07-25 14:45:08	@pingou	micro-frameworks are basically frameworks with little to no dependencies
2013-07-25 14:45:29	@pingou	in the case of flask, there are only 2: Werkzeug and Jinja
2013-07-25 14:45:53	@pingou	we will see jinja a little bit, but not really Werkzeug (although we will use it, within flask
2013-07-25 14:45:55	@pingou	)
2013-07-25 14:46:07	J_Caselles	!
2013-07-25 14:46:08	@pingou	let's start with jinja
2013-07-25 14:46:12	@pingou	> J_Caselles
2013-07-25 14:46:25	J_Caselles	what other types of web app framework exists?
2013-07-25 14:46:51	@pingou	J_Caselles: good question, the other framework are not really named
2013-07-25 14:47:20	@pingou	basically a framework like TurboGears comes with a lot of dependencies, all well-designed and aiming at helping you
2013-07-25 14:47:42	@pingou	however it means that you need to keep up with all of them and updating might become challenging :)
2013-07-25 14:47:59	J_Caselles	nice, thanks <eof>
2013-07-25 14:48:02	@pingou	with only 2 dependencies, flask is much easier to update and follow :)
2013-07-25 14:48:14	J_Caselles	:)
2013-07-25 14:48:35	@pingou	J_Caselles: for example, TurboGears imposes how you are connecting to a database
2013-07-25 14:48:46	@pingou	(same thing for Django)
2013-07-25 14:49:09	@pingou	flask does not do anything with databases, it will be up to you to set up your application the way you want it
2013-07-25 14:49:32	@pingou	so sometime micro-framework might give you a little more work when developing
2013-07-25 14:49:34	J_Caselles	so, it doesn't help you with everything, wich sometimes might be prefered
2013-07-25 14:50:22	@pingou	J_Caselles: indeed, it basically comes back to a balance between "all in one" vs "freedom to implement the way I want"

2013-07-25 14:52:21	@pingou	ok so let me quickly introduce what templates are
2013-07-25 14:52:50	@pingou	they are basically pages where you set some element as fix and leave some empty, to be filled later on
2013-07-25 14:53:00	@pingou	a bit like a form you fill for an administration
2013-07-25 14:53:14	@pingou	you have questions and cases for the answer
2013-07-25 14:53:27	@pingou	well in web development you will use template pretty much in the same way
2013-07-25 14:54:19	@pingou	except that instead of having "Date of birth: __/__/____" you will have "<title>{{title}}</title>"
2013-07-25 14:54:45	@pingou	where {{title}} is replaced by what you want
2013-07-25 14:55:05	@pingou	in web application you use the template to set the style of your pages
2013-07-25 14:55:33	@pingou	you have one main template, which defines the header at the top, the footer at the bottom, the column on the right/left with the menu
2013-07-25 14:55:49	@pingou	and somewhere in the middle you will put the content, content that changes from page to page

2013-07-25 15:43:24	@pingou	so this if __name__ == '__main__'
2013-07-25 15:43:37	J_Caselles	it runs whatever is inside if this code is run as script
2013-07-25 15:43:46	@pingou	exactly
2013-07-25 15:44:06	@pingou	which is useful as it prevents codes to be run if the file is imported into another file
2013-07-25 15:44:16	@pingou	so just to be clear
2013-07-25 15:44:38	@pingou	you know you can write some code into a file and run it via python <file>.py
2013-07-25 15:44:59	@pingou	you can also import in a file code from another file
2013-07-25 15:45:34	@pingou	that's pretty much what does the import <module> and from <module> import <function/class/variable>
2013-07-25 15:46:10	@pingou	but if you have a file test.py that contains "print('hello')" and have a second file test2.py with an import test
2013-07-25 15:46:17	@pingou	the print will be run at import
2013-07-25 15:46:32	@pingou	(which is not what's desired most of the time)
2013-07-25 15:47:16	@pingou	so having "if __name__ == '__main__': print('hello')" makes sure that the print is only executed if the file is directly run from python
2013-07-25 15:48:11	@pingou	personally I use this construct quite often when I want to test a module, just put it at the bottom of the file and have it call one of the function you wrote to test/debug it
2013-07-25 15:48:46	@pingou	do you see the interest of "if __name__ == '__main__'"?
